explanation:
The correct calculation applies the commutative property to each multiplication term separately: \( y \times x = x y \) and \( b \times 3 = 3 b \), then combines them as \( x y + 3 b \). 

The student incorrectly treated \( y \times x + b \times 3 \) as a single multiplication sequence, collapsing all elements into \( 3 b x y \). 

The error stems from misinterpreting the structure of the expression: the "+" operator separates the terms \( y \times x \) and \( b \times 3 \), but the student multiplied all numerical/alphabetic components together. This reflects a failure to recognize distinct terms in the expression and their additive relationship. 

The misconception aligns with multiplying all visible numbers/variables without analyzing their context (e.g., addition separating terms). It is distinct from purely misapplying the commutative property (which would involve term order within a product) or left-to-right calculation (which would preserve addition but miscalculate priorities).
